text: the moment of clarity that put me on the
entrepreneurial path was really getting
fired from a job I was working for a
software company with a an owner founder
CEO who had grown the company wildly
successful company really a household
name in its niche still but they are
still very successful and he and I had
fundamentally different views about how
to run things and so one day the c fo
and the founder came came in and said
martin is just not working and it's time
to pack your bags I was 40 years old it
was a huge blow to my ego clearly as
that had never been happening I had a
successful career before that and I
already knew I probably was a square peg
in a round hole but that's when I really
made the decision ok Martin it's time to
do this and I gave myself really 18
months or two years to find the right
industry and to start my own thing and
I've been doing that ever since I've
created a partnership back in 07 with a
couple of partners down in North
Carolina we raised to real estate
investment funds and we started
investing in real estate in 2008 which
turned out to be really good decision we
were buying undeveloped residential land
and we created 22 funds to go buy land
in three counties we ended up being the
largest land landowner in those three
counties and we're now selling property
still with great success I think the
biggest skill that I bring is the
skeptic being fundamentally an
operations person rather than a sales
and marketing person I'm always thinking
how I'm thinking how we going to get
over this obstacle how are we going to
address this challenge what are the
challenges what are the key risks how do
i identify the risks how to identify
ways of testing potential solutions to
the risk often you can't really afford
to do real tests against the real
problem but there might be some
interesting proxy that that is a pretty
good approximation of what the risk is
and how to prove against it or proof for
it and I'm exceptionally strong I think
it providing that kind of analytical
feedback I've had the good fortune in my
career of having some really great
mentors at some of the big companies
where I worked as well as some of the
smaller ones back in 97 98 I served on
Microsoft's very first Advisory Council
customer advisory council and I got had
a chance to interact with Bill Gates and
I asked bill what kept him up at night
and he kind of pause for a minute he
looked at me for four
10 or 15 seconds he said Martin I worry
that someone's going to do it better and
I think that coming from bill gates in
97 98 is really indicative of something
I think we should all remember as we
think about our careers we think about
our work we think about our companies we
think about what we do someone's going
to do it better and how do you stay out
ahead of that
